subject: THE POWER OF BAPTISM
verse:
This water [of the flood] symbolizes baptism that now saves
you also. (1 Peter 3:21)
reflection:
Christ’s Word on Holy Baptism is backed by His sin atoning
work. “Christ died for sins once for all, the righteous for
the unrighteous, to bring you to God” (I Peter 3:18). By
virtue of His all-sufficient atonement, as verified by His
resurrection. Baptism save because it creates and confirms
faith in the merit of Jesus Christ as Savior. Let me say;
The water of Baptism cleans up the messes that floods of sin
create.
prayer:
Lord Jesus, Your sin-atoning sacrifice makes baptism a
powerful means of grace, through which faith is created and
confirmed in Your saving merit. As the water cleanses, so
does Your Spirit wash away the floods of sin that overwhelm
us. Thank You for the promise that baptism connects us to
Your resurrection and new life, covering us with Your
righteousness and keeping us close to You. May this sacred
gift deepen our faith and strengthen our trust in Your
all-sufficient grace. Amen. (AI)

subject: WHO IS THE GREATEST
verse:
“If anyone wants to be first, he must be the very last, and
the servant of all.” (Mark 9:35)
reflection:
Jesus sat down to set the twelve straight: “If anyone wants
to be first, he must be the very last.” Jesus didn’t stop
with words. He gave the group an object lesson in humility.
He placed in their midst, a child who personified the kind
of faith and love that should mark every disciple, young or
old. The person who has a childlike-not childish-faith is a
true representative of Christ.
prayer:
Lord Jesus, thank You for teaching us that true greatness
comes from humble, childlike faith. Help us to embrace the
trust, dependence, and openness that children show, not with
childishness but with sincere humility. Teach us to follow
Your example by putting others first and receiving Your
kingdom with a pure heart. May our faith be marked by love
and simplicity, reflecting Your grace every day. Amen. (AI)

subject: WITH JESUS ON THE SEA OF LIFE
verse:
The disciples went down and woke Him, saying “Master,
Master, we’re going to drown!” (Luke 8:24)
reflection:
Caught in a strong squall on the sea of Galilee was a boat
carrying Jesus and His disciples. When the storm reached a
dangerous point the disciple felt they needed Jesus. They
woke Jesus and He stilled the storm. Jesus can-and
does-still storms arising in the human soul. Sin and fear of
death are like strong winds and waves disturbing our inner
calm. Like the disciples, we can confidently approach the
Lord with our prayers, for He is our Savior from sin, the
sovereign of life. Faith in Him assures us of His mercy and
frees us from all our faults.
prayer:
Lord Jesus, You are the calm in the storms of life, just as
You stilled the raging sea on the Sea of Galilee. When fear
and anxiety threaten to overwhelm us, help us to turn to You
in faith and trust Your sovereign power. Quiet the storms
within our souls, and grant us peace that surpasses all
understanding. Teach us to rely on Your mercy, knowing You
are our Savior from sin and the sovereign Lord over life.
With faith, we approach You confidently, trusting in Your
grace. Amen. (AI)

subject: A TIME OF SILENCE
verse:
Jesus withdrew from that place. Many followed Him, and He
healed all their sick, warning them not to tell who He was.
(Matthew 12:15-16)
reflection:
The quiet procedure of Jesus, is so different from the
publicity seeking actions of many would-be reformers and
crusaders. Matthew records the Messianic prophecy of Isaiah,
“He will not quarrel or cry out; no one will hear His voice
in the streets . . . till He leads justice to victory” (Matthew 12:19-20). The Messiah is presented as the Servant who
without self-promotion and fanfare, quickly, gently, and
tenderly did His work of healing the sick and nurturing
faith. Are we like that?
prayer:
Lord Jesus, Your quiet strength and gentle spirit stand in
contrast to the loud and boastful ways of the world. As
Isaiah prophesied and You fulfilled, You did not quarrel or
cry out in the streets but moved with tenderness and
humility in Your healing and teaching. Help us to follow
Your example-to serve and love without seeking applause or
attention, showing justice with patience and gentleness. May
our lives reflect Your quiet power and tender care for the
broken and weak, leading others to Your peace. Amen. (AI)

subject: STAYING CONNECTED
verse:
“I am the Vine, you are the branches. If a man remains In Me
and I in him, he will bear much fruit.” (John 15:5)
reflection:
In our spiritual lives, we need to be connected to the
higher power-God-to be effective in glorifying Him and
serving others. Jesus uses the illustration of a vine and
its branches. He identifies Himself as the vine and his
followers as branches. Jesus says, “No branch can bear fruit
by itself; it must remain in the vine. Neither can you bear
fruit unless you remain in Me” John 15: 4). We need to be
connected to the power source-Jesus Christ-if there are to
be the sweet grapes of the Words and works of Love. By the
power of the Holy Spirit, we were born again and given
faith. Faith is the critical connection.
prayer:
Lord Jesus, You are the true Vine, and we are the branches.
Help us to remain closely connected to You, drawing our
strength, life, and purpose from Your presence. May Your
Spirit bear fruit in our lives, showing love, kindness, and
faithfulness. Teach us to abide in You so that without You,
we can do nothing, but with You, we flourish and glorify the
Father. Amen.  (AI)

subject: THE POWER OF LOVE
verse:
“Greater love has no one than this, that he lay down his
life for his friends.” (John 15:13)
reflection:
Jesus the Bread of Life, gained salvation for all when in
love He became an atoning sacrifice on the cross. He called
His disciples His friends, telling them that love prompted
Him to lay down His life for them. What’s more, His
redeeming, life-give love extends to all mankind, including
His enemies. “When we were God’s enemies, we were reconciled
to Him through the death of His Son” (Romans 5:10). “Christ
died, that’s history. . .Christ died for you and me, that’s
salvation. “AMEN”
prayer:
Lord Jesus, You are the Bread of Life who loved us so deeply
that You laid down Your life as the perfect atoning
sacrifice on the cross. Your death reconciled us to the
Father, even when we were His enemies, showing the boundless
reach of Your redeeming love. Help us to remember that Your
sacrifice is not just history but our present salvation and
hope. May we live each day in gratitude for the grace You
have given us through Your sacrificial love. Amen.  (AI)

subject: WELL DRESSED WITH HUMILITY
verse:
All of you, cloth yourselves with humility toward one
another. (1 Peter 5:5)
reflection:
Humility is hard to define and even harder to live. What is
sometimes thought to be humility can be inverse pride, as in
being “proud of his humility.” Christian humility is a
virtue, a fruit of faith. The human heart is by nature
proud, but the Holy Spirit changed that when He brought us
to faith in Christ. With faith He gave humility, that is,
being what we are-no more--no less. It fits beautifully with
the fruit of the Spirit: love, joy, peace, patience,
kindness, and all the rest. It helps us to be more
Christ-like.
prayer:
Lord Jesus, humble my heart as You have taught through Your
perfect example. Help me to embrace true humility, not as
false pride, but as faithful recognition of who I am in Your
sight—no more, no less. Fill me with the fruit of the
Spirit-love, joy, peace, patience, and kindness-so that I
may reflect Your character and walk humbly with You each
day. Teach me to serve others with grace, always trusting
Your strength in my weakness. Amen.

subject: GOD CAN DO IT
verse:
You will drink from the brook, and I have ordered the ravens
to feed you there. (1 Kings 17:4)
reflection:
Does God use lesser creatures to preserve the lives of
people? As a matter of fact, He does so regularly as He
provides for our bodily needs through things that grow in
nature. God can do it also through special
interventions-miracles-as He did for the prophet Elijah. A
miracle in a special sense occurred when we came to saving
faith in Jesus Christ. Thank the Lord for His many
kindnesses to you-especially for the miracle of bring you to
faith in Jesus Christ.
prayer:
Lord God, You use all of Your creation to care for and
sustain us, even lesser creatures like animals. Just as You
sent ravens to feed Elijah and used a whale to redirect
Jonah, You intervene in our lives through the miraculous and
the ordinary. Thank You especially for the greatest miracle
of all-the gift of saving faith in Jesus Christ. May we
always recognize Your hand in the world around us and give
thanks for Your kindness and provision. Amen.  (AI)

subject: RETRACING ONE’S STEPS
verse: The Lord said to him, “Go back the way you came.” (1 Kings 19:15)
reflection:
Many people try to run away from God, only to be found by
Him and told, “Go back the way you came.” No disgrace
follows such a return. One does not lose self-respect or the
esteem of others to admit the mistake of choosing a wrong
destination and the wrong way of getting there. People who
like the prodigal-son in Jesus’ parable, come back to God to
find His ready acceptance. Those who go into hiding because
they are discouraged, as Elijah was, can return to God and
to the service into which He called them. “The problem . . .
is to find out which way God is going and to go that way.
prayer:
Lord God, thank You for Your unfailing love that welcomes us
back no matter how far we have strayed. Like the prodigal
son, help me to find the courage to return to Your embrace
without shame or fear. Guide me to follow the path You have
set, trusting in Your mercy and readiness to restore. May I
always listen for Your voice pointing the way and walk
faithfully in Your light. Amen.

subject: NO ONE IS TO SMALL
verse: [Zacchaeus] wanted to see who Jesus was, but being a short man he could not see. (Luke 19:3)
reflection:
Zacchaeus, the tax collector in Jericho, was small but that
did not keep him from seeing Jesus or Jesus from seeing him.
Life’s circumstances height, age, income-are of no
significance to Jesus. Because of original sin, we are all
on the same level in the sight of God. In Christ, the
Mediator, He has compassion on us all. Our Lord is concerned
about little people. He accepts and blesses the little
children we bring to Him in Holy Baptism. The Lord has a
heart for all.
prayer:
Lord Jesus, just as You saw Zacchaeus despite his small
stature and past, see me with compassion and love. Remind me
that life's circumstances do not limit Your care and grace.
Help me to trust in Your heart that embraces all, especially
the little and overlooked. May I come to You with childlike
faith, knowing that in Your sight, I am deeply valued and
blessed. Amen. (AI)

subject: GOD OVERRULES HUMAN ERROR
verse: You intended to harm me, but God intended it for good to accomplish what is now being done, the saving of many lives. (Genesis 50:20)
reflection:
God has a way of turning human errors so it fulfills His
will. This truth clearly emerges from the story of Joseph in
the Old Testament, where his brothers because of their
jealousy sold him into slavery. Through this act Joseph rose
from slavery into leadership. Turning to the New Testament,
we see even more clearly how God turned the hatred of Jesus’
enemies into the good of mankind, turning the brutal
crucifixion into the once-for-all sacrifice of His Son.
While God carries out His will, the evildoers are still
accountable to Him for their sins. Let us praise our Lord
for all His blessings to us.
prayer:
Lord God, Your ways are higher than ours, turning human
mistakes into part of Your divine plan. Like Joseph, who was
sold into slavery by his brothers but rose to save many, You
transform what seems broken into blessings. Through the
suffering and sacrifice of Your Son Jesus, You have redeemed
the world, turning evil into our salvation. Help us to trust
in Your providence, praising You for Your mercy and
faithfulness in all things. Amen. (AI)

subject: ONE LORD JESUS CHRIST
verse: Is Christ divided? (1 Corinthians 1:13)
reflection:
When Paul asked the Corinthian church, “Is Christ divided?”
He was referring to the division in the congregation with
some saying they followed Paul or Apollos or Cephas, and the
like. This Paul maintained, is dividing Christ and
effectively destroying the unity of faith in Christ. Paul
told the church, “there is one body and one Spirit just as
you were called to one hope when you were called-one Lord,
one faith, one Baptism; one God and Father of all” (Ephesians 4:4-6). Satan as always tried to divide Christ, and so
destroying the unity in the church
prayer:
Lord Jesus, You are the one true Head of the Church, and we
thank You for calling us into unity through one Spirit, one
faith, and one baptism. Help us to resist divisions and
instead focus on You as our Lord and Savior. May we remember
that no human leader was crucified for us-only You-and that
our loyalty belongs solely to You. Unite our hearts in love
and purpose, so that we may reflect Your oneness and glory
to the world. Amen. (AI)

subject: OUR WELL-STOCKED WARDROBE
verse: “What shall we wear?” (Matthew 6:31)
reflection:
There is much more to the question that is asked in Matthew 6:31. If Jesus would not have come as our Savior, we would
have asked, “What shall we wear?” with regard to the
spiritual clothes we need as we stand before God on the Last
Day and every day. Thank God we know His answer to the
question, “for He has clothed me in garments of salvation
and arrayed me in a robe of righteousness” (Isaiah 61:10) The
Gospel bid us to trust in the atoning merit of Jesus Christ
and be clothed in the robes of righteousness.
prayer:
Righteous Father, thank You that in Christ You have clothed
me with garments of salvation and a robe of righteousness.
Quiet my anxious questions, and teach me to trust the
atoning merit of Jesus rather than my own efforts. Let me
walk each day robed in Your grace, rejoicing in the Gospel
that covers and renews me. Amen. (AI)

subject: A WORDLESS PRAYER
verse: [Jesus] asked him, “Do you want to get well?” (John 5:6)
reflection:
Jesus visited a well-known pool near one of Jerusalem’s
gates. The place was called Bethesda, literally a house of
mercy. When an angel stirred the pool the first one to step
in would be healed. Jesus approached a man who had lain
beside the pool for 38 years and asked if he wanted to get
well. The patient could have answered, “Of course I do, why
do you think I’ve been laying here?” But he answered Jesus,
who was unknown to him, with respect: “Sir ... I have no one
to help me into the pool when the water is stirred. The man
had not spoken words of prayer, but Jesus knew the man’s
desire. He said, “Get up . . . and walk” (John 5:8).
Immediately the man got up and walked. Sincere prayer may
consist of many words, a few words, or none-at-all. What is
important is He who searches our hearts knows the mind of
the Spirit, who intercedes for the believer in accordance
with God’s will” (Romans 8:26-27). Our Lord knows what is in
our heart when in faith we come to Him with words or
without.
prayer:
Lord Jesus, You see our need even before we speak, and You
know the desires we can’t put into words. Search my heart,
meet me with Your mercy, and speak the healing command that
lifts me to walk in faith. Teach me to trust the Spirit’s
intercession and to come to You—whether with many words,
few, or none at all. Amen. (AI)

subject: JESUS COMES OUR WAY
verse:
As Jesus and His disciple … were leaving the city, a blind
man, Bartimaeus … was sitting by the roadside begging. (Mark 10:46)
reflection:
Everyone of us, at one time or another, experience some kind
of distress. If it isn’t a physical disability it is
something else: financial worries, health concerns, career
challenges, loneliness, or any number of other challenges.
But there is help and hope. We are greatly blessed to have
Jesus, Helper and Healer, come our way. The Savior, having
made us His own, comes our way on the feet of human
messengers: friends, family, and fellow Christians in whose
hearts the love of God is working. The question before every
Christian should be: How can we be a messenger for Christ to
people in need.
prayer:
Lord Jesus, Helper and Healer, meet us in every
distress—body, mind, and spirit—and bring Your comfort and
hope. Fill our hearts with Your love so we become Your
messengers: attentive to needs, swift to pray, generous to
serve, and brave to bear Your gospel. Send us to the lonely,
the worried, and the hurting, that through our hands and
words they may meet You. Amen. (AI)

subject: PRAISING GOD IN OUR SONGS
verse:
[The Lord] put a new song in my mouth, a hymn of praise to
our God. (Psalm 40:3)
reflection:
There are occasions when new songs are very much in order,
such as the anniversary of a church or happy events in the
life of a Christian. But as we know there are some people
who are not fond of new songs, preferring the old, familiar
ones. Then we have others who prefer new things. Old songs
or new, our intention should be to give praise to God,
always giving thanks to God the Father for everything, in
the name of our Lord Jesus Christ (Ephesians 5:19, 20). God led
us out of sin right to Jesus Christ, whose atoning sacrifice
gives us much to rejoice and sing about.
prayer:

hearts to praise You with gratitude in all things. Thank You
for leading us out of sin to Jesus Christ, whose atoning
sacrifice gives us endless reasons to rejoice and sing. Let
our worship—traditional or fresh—be pleasing to You and
filled with the Spirit. Amen. (AI)

subject: A SPIRITUAL HARVEST
verse:
“Unless a kernel of wheat falls to the ground and dies, it
remains a single seed. But if it dies, it produces many
seeds.” (John 12:24)
reflection:
It’s amazing, how a germinated seed multiplies into many of
its kind. It can’t be looked at in any other way then a
miracle, but because it occurs so regularly we call it a
natural process. Now Jesus had to die and be buried before
there could be fruits of His redemption. His resurrection
gave the assurance of the sufficiency of His sacrifice. Our
Savior is still gathering a harvest, With Us As His Workers!
prayer:
Lord Jesus, thank You that Your death and resurrection have
borne a harvest of redemption. Plant Your life deep within
me, and make me a faithful worker in Your fields—sowing the
gospel, watering with love, and trusting You for the growth.
Gather a plentiful harvest for Your glory in our day. Amen.
(AI)

subject: SPIRITUAL GROWTH
verse:
Like newborn babies, crave spiritual milk, so that by it you
may grow up in your salvation. (1 Peter 2:2)
reflection:
What Is Needed in This Life: The people the apostle
addressed in his letter were New Christians. Spiritually
speaking they were babies. A good beginning had been made,
but newcomers in the faith need to grow. As we should see
the apostle clearly explained how spiritual growth comes
about. The proper nourishment for beginners is the “pure
spiritual milk,” the simple Word of God. It teaches that all
people are sinners and that Jesus Christ is their only
Savior: and are redeemed by the precious blood of Christ, a
lamb without blemish or defect (I Peter 1:18-19) Our calling
is to be Christians who daily grow in the knowledge and
faith of Christ.
prayer:
Father, nourish me with the pure spiritual milk of Your
Word, that I may grow daily in the knowledge and faith of
Christ. Keep my heart humble like a newborn, hungry for
truth, and anchor me in the precious redemption won by
Jesus’ spotless blood. Make my beginnings mature into
steadfast obedience and living hope. Amen. (AI)

subject: DOING THE CHURCH'S BUSINESS
verse:
“It is written, … My house will be called a house of
prayer.” (Matthew 21:13)
reflection:
Jesus objected when in the temple courtyard merchants sold
animals intended for sacrifice and operated currency
exchange for profit. He objects today when people turn God’s
house into a marketplace and transact business. To us
“church” is more then a building. It is God’s people, who
believed themselves to be redeemed by Jesus Christ, serve
Him on Sundays and weekdays and profess Him before the
world. Our Lord made it the business of the church to “make
disciples of all nations, baptizing them in the name of the
Father and of the Son, and of the Holy Spirit, and teaching
them to obey everything I have commanded you” (Matthew 28:19-20)
prayer:
Heavenly Father, we ask You to cleanse Your house and our
hearts from anything that turns Your church into a
marketplace. May Your people serve You sincerely,
proclaiming the Gospel and making disciples with humility
and love. Help us to keep Christ at the center, honoring
Your house as a place of worship, prayer, and service to the
world. Amen. (Al)

subject: THE SON OF GOD SLEEPS
verse: Jesus was in the stern, sleeping on a cushion. (Mark 4:38)
reflection:
That Jesus slept, is truly meaningful as well as comfort ing. It proves that God had assumed a true human nature. He
did not pretend to be human, was not an actor who came on
stage as somebody else. He was in fact a true human-being
who fit Himself into our situation. He knows from personal
experience what it means to be bone tired, to need rest
in-the-midst of life’s storms, to be able to bear only so
much physically and emotionally. What this tells us is we
have a Savior who is able to “Sympathize with our weaknesses
... one who has been tempted in every way, just as we are-yet

do. In the midst of life's storms, may we find comfort

rests in perfect peace, fully trusting in Your sovereign
care. Teach us to trust You with the same confidence,
resting in Your presence even when the storms rage around
us. Amen. (AI)

subject: NAMES WRITTEN IN THE LAMB'S BOOK OF LIFE
verse:
O Lord, the hope of Israel, all who forsake You will be put
to shame. Those who turn away from You will be written in
the dust. (Jeremiah 17:13)
reflection:
To have one’s name written in the dust is to stand under
God’s judgment for one’s sins. When a woman taken in
adultery was brought before Jesus, He bent down to write on
the ground with His finger. Jesus went to the cross so we
might have eternal life and have our names written, not in
sand or dust, but in granite. Those who believe in Jesus as
their Savior and Lord have been enrolled “In the Lamb’s book
of life” (Revelation 21:27). They are not only saved, but safe safe in the hands of Jesus, where no enemy can reach them of
delete their names from God’s list.
prayer:
Heavenly Father, we thank You for the powerful reminder in
the story of Jesus writing in the dust, showing Your mercy
over judgment. Through Christ's sacrifice, our names are not
written in dust but engraved eternally in the Lamb's Book of
Life, securing our salvation and safety in Your loving
hands. Help us to live with the assurance of Your grace,
confident that nothing can erase the salvation You've
secured for us. Amen. (AI)

*Subject: NAMES WRITTEN IN THE LAMB'S BOOK OF LIFE*

(read Col. 2:6-15)

*The Verse for Today:*

*O Lord, the hope of Israel, all who forsake You will*

*be put to shame. Those who turn away from You*

*will be written in the dust. *(Jer. 17:13)



*Let’s Give This Verse Some Thought:*

To have one’s name written in the dust is to stand

under God’s judgement for one’s sins. When a woman

taken in adultery was brought before Jesus, He bent

down to write on the ground with His finger. Jesus

went to the cross so we might have eternal life and

have our names written, not in sand or dust, but in

granite. Those who believe in Jesus as their Savior

and Lord have been enrolled *“In the Lamb’s book of*

*life” *(Rev. 21:27). *They are not only saved, but safe—*

*safe in the hands of Jesus, where no enemy can reach*

*them of delete their names from God’s list.*

* Pastor Al*

subject: SIN AND GRACE
verse:
I know that nothing good lives in me, that is, in my nature.
(Romans 7:18) The acts of a sinful nature are obvious. (Galatians 5:19)
reflection:
This account illustrates the twofold aspect of sin: original
and actual. The former is a condition, the latter its
enactment. The apostle Paul wrote that nothing good dwells
in our inner nature, and this pre-conversion hatred and
persecutions of Christians prove it. Paul taught what Jesus
stressed: “Flesh gives birth to flesh” (John 3:6) and “Out of
the heart come evil thoughts, murder, adultery, sexual
immorality, theft, false testimony, slander” (Matthew 15:19).
But there is salvation. Jesus, the sinless Son of God, was
made to be sin for us that we by faith might be made
righteous in God’s sight. How wonderful is God’s forgiving
grace: “Where sin increased, grace increased all-the-more”
(Romans 5:20).
prayer:
Heavenly Father, we acknowledge our sinfulness and the
darkness within us, yet we rejoice in Your abundant grace
that covers all our transgressions. Thank You for sending
Jesus, who was sinless yet made to be sin for us, so that by
faith we might become righteous in Your sight. Help us to
live in the freedom and hope of Your forgiveness, trusting
in Your love that increases even as our sin does. Amen. (AI)

subject: SOLID NOURISHMENT
verse: Then Jesus declared, “I am the bread of Life.” (John 6:35)
reflection:
“Man does not live by bread alone,” Jesus said, quoting
(Deuteronomy 8:3).Moses pointed out that God taught the Israelites
a lesson when He gave them manna in the wilderness as an
unearned gift. The point is: people depended on God’s power
as the Provider. He supplies our spiritual provisions, the
needed soul food. Jesus taught the same lesson when He fed
multitudes in uninhabited places. Jesus declared Himself to
be the “Bread of life,” adding that “he who comes to Me will
never grow hungry”(John 6:35). The Gospel satisfies the
hunger and thirst of the soul.
prayer:
Heavenly Father, thank You for sending Jesus as the Bread of
Life who satisfies the deepest hunger of our souls. Help us
to come to Him daily, trusting in His provision and grace
that sustains us eternally. May we always remember that our
true nourishment and life come from You alone. Amen. (AI)

subject: TEMPLES OF THE HOLY SPIRIT
verse:
Do you not know that your body is a temple of the Holy
Spirit, who is in you, whom you have received from God? (1 Corinthians 6:19)
reflection:
Our whole makeup belongs to God. We confess God to be the
maker of heaven and earth, and so is also Creator of each
person’s body and soul. But there is more. Not only do we
belong to God because He made us and the Son of God redeemed
us, but also because the Holy Spirit lives in us to
enlighten us with His gifts, sanctify us, and keeps us in
the true faith. So it is important that we welcome Him
through holy living.
prayer:
Heavenly Father, Creator of body and soul, we thank You for
making us and redeeming us through Your Son. We are grateful
that Your Holy Spirit dwells within us to enlighten,
sanctify, and keep us in true faith. Help us to welcome and
honor the Spirit by living holy lives that reflect Your love
and grace. Amen. (Al)

subject: SIN and SALVATION
verse:
All have sinned and fall short of the glory of God, and are
justified freely by His grace through the redemption that
came by Christ Jesus. (Romans 3:23-24)
reflection:
The first truth is law, The Bible’s message of the reality
of sin. Through our first parents. Adam and Eve, sin has
come down on all humanity. Sin exacts death as the penalty.
The next truth is Gospel, God’s grace extending to all. This
grace means free, unearned, and unmerited salvation: the
forgiveness of sins, the promise of eternal life, and
spiritual newness. Salvation by God’s grace comes to us
through the merits of Christ, who atoned for the sin of the
world. The triad of truths “by grace alone,” “for Christ’s
sake alone,” and “though faith alone” has a fourth dimension
sola Scriptura. This is to say that the Bible is the only
source of what is taught in the church. By believing in
Christ as the risen Lord and Savior we become the
beneficiaries of His righteousness and holiness.
prayer:
Heavenly Father, thank You for the gift of Your Law that
reveals our need for salvation and Your Gospel that offers
grace through Jesus Christ. Help us to embrace Your Word
fully, trusting not in our own works but in the
righteousness You provide by faith alone. May Your Spirit
guide us to live in the freedom and newness that comes from
Your grace, rooted firmly in Your Word. Amen. (AI)

*Verse for Today:*

*All have sinned and fall short of the glory of God,*

*and are justified freely by His grace through the*

*redemption that came by Christ Jesus. *(Romans 3:23-24)



*Truths to Remember:*

The first truth is law, The Bible’s message of the

reality of sin. Through our first parents. Adam

and Eve, sin has come down on all humanity. Sin

exacts death as the penalty.

The next truth is Gospel, God’s grace extending to

all. This grace means *free*, *unearned*, and *unmerited*

*salvation*: the forgiveness of sins, the promise of

eternal life, and spiritual newness. Salvation by God’s

grace comes to us through the merits of Christ, who

atoned for the sin of the world.

The triad of truths “by grace alone,” “for Christ’s sake

alone,” and “though faith alone” has a fourth dimension

*sola Scriptura. *This is to say that the Bible is the only

source of what is taught in the church.

*By believing in Christ as the risen Lord and Savior we*

*become the beneficiaries of His righteousness and*

*holiness.*

*Pastor Al*
